conclusion: Objects A and B are airborne, and objects C, D, E, and F are stationary on the surface where A and B will land.
Objects A and B move through the air and are placed down at locations C, D, E, and F respectively, as indicated by the arrows.
When object A lands on the surface, it experiences the force of gravity and collides with object C.
When object B lands on the surface, it impacts object D.
The same principle applies when both A and B reach their respective positions (C and D), and the collision happens due to the gravitational pull.
Upon landing, objects A and B will cause deformation or displacement in the surfaces where they land because they are not perfectly elastic and have mass.
The impact will displace the fabrics (C, D, E, F) slightly, depending on the material properties and the weight of A and B.
In picture 2, there are slight deformations around the placement area of A and B, indicating that the materials are not rigid and can compress under the weight.
Object A will be situated on top of fabric C after the impact.
Object B will be situated on top of fabric D after the impact.
Fabrics C and D will show some indentation or shift due to the weight and material properties of A and B.
If the surfaces are soft and flexible, like fabric, the fabrics will sink slightly under the weight of A and B.
If the surfaces are rigid or hard, the impact would result in minimal change, except for minor pressure marks.
